entry.title: Re: The Detail of Service Contract cannot Display
entry.content: If the detail of a Service Contract isnâ€™t displaying, itâ€™s usually caused by a missing permission, a broken reference, or a UI configuration issue. First, check whether the user has the correct access rights to view contract detailsâ€”especially roles, field-level security, and object permissions. Next, confirm that the Service Contract record is linked correctly to related objects (like accounts or line items). If the page layout was recently modified, ensure the detail section or component is still included and visible. Finally, clear cache or test in incognito to rule out UI caching issues. These steps typically resolve missing contract detail views.

entry.title: Sales Order Kitting in SAP S4HANA PUBLIC CLOUD
entry.content:
Hi SAP Gurus,

We want to perform sales order kitting process in SAP S4HANA Public cloud without production order cycle.

Header Material is XYZ (This is kit material)

Components are below

A 1 pcs

B 1 pcs

C 1 pcs

We have created a BOM for XYZ with BOM usages as 5 and added 3 components

We want to know what should be general item category group for all the 4 items - it should be NORM ?

When the sales order is created - as per BOM's, components should be exploded, and warehouse needs to post goods issue of components in EWM. We don't want to show kit components on billing documents, only want header Material in billing documents.

Bom components should be reduced by 1 pc each and header material quantity should be generated by 1

Please help me with the process.

@Lakshmipathi 

 

Thanks !

entry.title: how to set the data effective date always equal to the end date of a range filter?
entry.content:
Hi, I'm building a report to analyze hiring quality in SF story report by calculating the 12-month rolling retention rate (% of new hires still with company).

I've encountered a data recency issue. Since employee status is live, the report results change daily. I need the results for a specific period to be fixed.

For example (Oct 2024 - Sep 2025):

  • 95 new hires in total.
  • Today's data: 15 are left.
  • Data as of Sep 30, 2025: 12 are left.

My Goal: I want the report to always use the status as of the period's end date (e.g., Sep 30, 2025 for the Oct 24-Sep 25 period), regardless of when the report is run.

Is there a solution to automatically set the "Data Effective Date" to equal the "Duration End Date"?

Thanks for your help.

entry.title: What Is SAP-RPT-1? A Table-Specialized Model Explained Through the original RPT Paper
entry.content:
At TechEd Berlin, SAP announced SAP-RPT-1. Since then, I often hear questions like: "Is this model an LLM?", "How is it different from Joule?"

In fact, the idea behind SAP-RPT-1 is not completely new. There is a research paper from 2020 titled "RPT: Relational Pre-trained Transformer Is Almost All You Need towards Democratizing Data Preparation".
In this post, I will not go deep into the SAP-RPT-1 product itself. Instead, I will look at the original RPT paper and explain the architecture behind it. (SAP officially describes SAP-RPT-1 as a â€œRelational Pretrained Transformerâ€ and positions it as a foundation model for business. The product version is tuned more for real business use cases than the original research model.)

 

What is In-Context Learning?

The official SAP-RPT-1 page describes it like this:

â€œSAP-RPT-1 is a relational pretrained transformer model that delivers accurate predictive insights from structured business data. SAP-RPT-1 uses in-context learning, allowing users to provide data records to generate instant, reliable predictions without any model training.â€

So, what is in-context learning?

In short, you take a model that is already trained, give it a few example records together with your question, and the model uses the pattern in those examples to produce an answer.

You can think of it like this kind of quiz:

The important point is:

  • You are only showing examples.
  • You are not changing the modelâ€™s internal parameters.

The model was trained before. Now you only give it context (examples) at run time, and it uses that context to reason.

 

In-Context Learning vs "Learning"

In-context learning is not the same as â€œlearningâ€ in the usual machine learning sense.

In normal â€œlearningâ€ or â€œtrainingâ€:

  • The model updates its parameters using training data.
  • This happens in pre-training or fine-tuning.

In in-context learning:

  • The model parameters are not updated.
  • You only change the input (the prompt), not the model itself.
  • This technique is often called few-shot prompting.

On the other hand, the term few-shot learning is usually used when you actually train or fine-tune the model again. But you use only a small number of labeled examples.

In in-context learning, the real â€œlearningâ€ (pre-training, fine-tuning) is already done. The model has become a kind of huge pattern recognition machine. When you show a few examples in the prompt, it behaves as if it learned a new task on the spot and gives reasonable answers. We donâ€™t fully see how it works internally (it feels like a black box), but we can use this behavior.

 

What is Relational Pre-trained Transformer (RPT)?

Modern large language models (LLMs) are trained with Next Token Prediction. They read a huge amount of text and learn to predict the next token (word, subword, etc.) from the previous tokens. By doing this, they learn grammar, vocabulary, how to follow instructions, and many other patterns in natural language. The interesting part is when the model is trained on a lot of data, it can guess or infer information that was not explicitly given, and be used for many different tasks. These models are called foundation models, they are pre-trained on broad data and can be adapted to many downstream tasks.

Relational Pre-trained Transformer (RPT) applies a similar idea, but to relational / table data, not free text. RPT was originally proposed to automate data preparation tasks such as data cleaning, filling, missing values, and so on. 

RPT takes pairs of attribute [A] and value [V] as input. For example, a tuple (row) can be represented like this:

[A] name [V] Michael Jordan [A] expertise [V] Machine Learning [A] city [V] Berkeley

This is one record (one row) written as a sequence. RPT then masks either an attribute or a value and tries to predict it.

  • Masking an attribute name
    Hide the attribute name and let the model guess it from the rest.
    Example: [A] name [V] Michael Jordan -> [A] [M] [V] Michael Jordan
  • Masking an attribute value
    Hide the value and let the model predict what should be there.
    Example: [A] expertise [V] Machine Learning -> [A] expertise [V] [M]

By training on many tuples like this,  as a result, RPT becomes a model specialized for table data preparation, such as:

  • data cleaning (detecting and fixing wrong values),
  • missing value imputation (filling empty cells),
  • schema matching (deciding which value belongs to which column).

So you can think of RPT not as a model that writes the next sentence like LLM, but as a model that: "Looks at one row of a table and is very good at fixing or completing it."

 

Why Is SAP-RPT-1 Called a "Predictive Model"?

This tuple-based training is a great fit for tabular data (Attributes = columns in a table, Values = cells in each row).  RPT models learn the patterns of (column, value) pairs very well. After pre-training, they can look at a new record (row) and ask "What value is likely for this column?".

SAP-RPT-1 is described as a "predictive model" because it can use existing records as teachers via in-context learning. When we call the API, we can send some existing records (historical data) and a target record with some missing values. The model reads the patterns in the context records. Then it predicts the missing cell(s) in the target record. So SAP-RPT-1 behaves like a predictive model for tables.

In short:

  • RPT (paper version) is a data preparation model that fills and fixes missing or noisy values in tuples.
  • SAP-RPT-1 (product version) is a foundation predictive model for tabular business data, built on the RPT idea and extended for business use.

The architecture comes from the RPT family. On top of that, SAP-RPT-1 can do classification and regression on table data via in-context learning, which is why it is promoted as a predictive model.

 

Conclusion

Finally, SAP-RPT-1 has a Playground that you can try. On the official website, click "Try SAP-RPT-1 for free" and test it with your own data or a simple example. With a GUI, you can upload a small table and quickly see what inputs you give and what predictions come back. If you read the RPT paper and then play with the Playground, your understanding of SAP-RPT-1 will grow much faster.

entry.title: When Physical Identity Turns Digital: Rethinking Traceability in Enterprise Integration
entry.content:
Modern large scale integration architectures are powered by advance resurgence of observability, distributed tracing, and correlations.
The advancement in observability and analytics platform, provides confidence to extend the reach of integration and envision more on horizon.

The traceability improvement is not limited to the digital world.
The evolutionary spiral is expanding in the realms of supply chain operations, infobahn and data reservoirs.

With EPCIS(Electronic Product Code Information Services) upgrade to version 2.0, the business events, propagating downstream, upstream or in the reverse logistic channel- can be wrapped in json-ld/json file and can be upserted at each stage of the supply chain to the next.

Key EPC identifiers are GTIN, SGTIN(Combination of serial number and GTIN), GRAI(Global Returnable Asset Identifier) and SSCC(Serial Shipping Container Code).

The core idea of this blog is to use the physical EPC(Electronic Product Code) identifiers as W3C trace context identifiers such as traceparent and tracestate.
Each integrated (and OTEL observable) cloud/web application , in case forwards, these identifiers from one system to other, as part of HTTP headers then the organizations can establish strong correlation between physical supply chain events and digital system interactions. A major leverage point of these headers, would be the scenarios, where asynchronous request and response is used at larger scale for e.g. usage of SAP Event Mesh, JMS Queues etc.

For supply-chain leaders and digital-transformation executives, the multi-fold benefits are clear:
a unified, correlated view of physical events and digital flows, enabling deeper insights, quicker decisions, and more successful operations. From a different vantage point, the digital trails set by W3C trace context, reflects the recording of physical events by the digital systems as traceparent/tracestate, whenever the system digitally observes a product related event(specified by EPCIS jason-ld file) passing through it.

Following are few methods to set/derive the W3C trace context using epc ids:
- Set traceparent as hash of epc id.
- Set tracestate as epc id.
- Set trace-id field of traceparent as epc id(if epc id is a UUID).

Below you would find an http client snippet which performs the above suggested steps.  The snippet below is only for didactic purpose.

with open("epcis_payload.json", "r", encoding="utf-8") as file:
    payload = json.load(file)

#epcis file itself can carry traceparent as part of extension field; if present extract and set it 
traceParent = None
if 'extension' in payload:
    if 'traceContext' in payload['extension']:
        if 'traceparent' in payload['extension']['traceContext']:
            traceParent = payload['extension']['traceContext']['traceparent']

#Otherwise, hash the epc id and set traceparent with the obtained value post hashing             
if traceParent == None:            
    # Create deterministic 16 byte trace ID
    if 'epcList' in payload:
        traceId = hashlib.sha256(str(payload['epcList']).encode()).hexdigest()[:32]
    else:
        traceId = str(uuid.uuid4())[:32]
    span_uuid = uuid.uuid4()
    spanId = str(span_uuid)
    #traceparent = 00-<trace-id>-<span-id>-01
    traceParent = '00-' + traceId + '-' + spanId[:16] + '-01'

#Add traceparent as http header 
headers.update({"traceparent": traceParent})

#epcis file itself can carry tracestate as part of extension field; if present extract and set it
traceState = ""
if 'extension' in payload:
    if 'traceContext' in payload['extension']:
        if 'traceState' in payload['extension']['traceContext']:
            traceState = payload['extension']['traceContext']['traceState']

#Otherwise, set the tracestate as epc id           
if traceState == "":
        if 'epcList' in payload: 
            # Create tracestate from EPCIS Id
            traceState = 'epcList = ' + str(payload['epcList'])
        if 'inputEPCList' in payload:
            # Extend the tracestate
            if 'epcList' in traceState:
                traceState = traceState + ',' + 'inputEPCList = ' + str(payload['inputEPCList'])
            else:
                traceState = 'inputEPCList = ' + str(payload['inputEPCList'])
        if 'outputEPCList' in payload:
            traceState = traceState + ',' + 'outputEPCList = ' + str(payload['outputEPCList'])

#Add tracestate as http header 
headers.update({"tracestate": traceState})

#POST request
response = requests.post(url, auth=HTTPBasicAuth(username, password), headers=headers, json=payload)

The EPCIS json-ld/json file forwarder, can even send traceparent and tracestate(as part of extension field of the file) along with business event details.

In the Runtime Configuration of Integration Flow, set traceparent and tracestate as allowed headers (as shown below):

One can even think of embedding the returned MPL ID (from SAP Integration Suite. as part of HTTP response), into tracestate for further transmission down the lane. Later, the predecessor MPL IDs and Integration Flows involved, in processing, the EPCIS json-Ld, can be determined as per explanation in following help documentation:
https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-integration/sap-cloud-integration/using-ids-to-filter-messages?locale=en-US&q=predecessor

An EPCIS event describes what, where, why, when and how about the business event. Taking an abstract look to overall above suggested scheme-  it would appear as if a new dimension is added to EPCIS event i.e. who(digitally viewed the event).


Now imagine that the integrated systems are streaming these message headers to data lake such as SAP Business Data Cloud or to a data federation system. This would then open a new portal to the world of federated tracing and large scale correlation. By indexing with traceparent, the correlated messages, in data lake and federation system, can be brought together.

Additionally, the W3C trace context headers can be stored as custom header properties, in message processing logs, in SAP Integration Suite. These settings can be achieved by (AI assisted) groovy scripting in SAP Integration Suite.

Below snippet reflects the extraction of traceparent and tracestate from the http header and setting the same as MPL's custom headers.

def messageLog = messageLogFactory.getMessageLog(message)
    
    if(messageLog != null) {
        messageLog.addAttachmentAsString(attachmentName, body, "text/plain")
    } 
    def traceid = message.getHeader("traceparent", String.class)
    messageLog.addCustomHeaderProperty("traceparent", traceid)
    
    def tracestate = message.getHeader("tracestate", String.class)
    messageLog.addCustomHeaderProperty("tracestate", tracestate)

One can then view these custom headers, in Message Monitor section of SAP Integration Suite, as shown below:

 

The added custom attributes would be then visible, in SAP Cloud ALM as well, provided the respective SAP Integration Suite and  SAP Cloud ALM tenants are already dovetailed.

Harvest above insights and ideas and redefine the observability of supply chains !


References:
https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-integration/sap-cloud-integration/message-processing-log-text-view?locale=en-US
https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-alm/apis/raw-data-inbound-logs?locale=en-US

entry.title: Re: Restrict Consumption of raw material from specific st...
entry.content:
Some standard options you can explore are

In the MRP 2 view of the material master, you can define a default issue storage location. During confirmation, the system will propose this storage location. If you want to prevent â€œStoreâ€ from being used, simply do not maintain it as the issue location. However, users could still manually override it unless you add further controls.

In routing or production version, you can assign the correct storage location for components. This ensures that during backflush, the system always picks the intended storage location. Again, this is a proposal, not a hard block

Use authorization objects for storage location like M_MATE_LGO or M_MSEG_LGO. Restrict users so they cannot post goods movements from the â€œStoreâ€ location. Then, even if they try to override in CO11N, the posting will fail due to missing authorization. This is the most effective way in Public Cloud, since enhancements are not available.

entry.title: How to Validate an S/4HANA Business Case During the Discover Phase: A PMâ€™s Real Checklist
entry.content:
When we start an S/4HANA project, the business case is usually the first document everyone refers to. In reality, the business case is often created long before the full project team arrives â€” sometimes by a pre-sales team, sometimes by IT leadership, and sometimes by business leaders who describe goals in very high-level terms.

In my current S/4HANA program in Saudi Arabia for a Food & Beverages customer, the Discover phase exposed several gaps that forced us to rethink the original business case. Iâ€™ve learned that this phase isnâ€™t just a formality â€” itâ€™s where we find out whether the transformation objectives are real or just assumptions.

Below is a practical checklist I use as a PM during Discover to validate the business case before stepping into Prepare.

1. Understand the Real Drivers

In one of our meetings, the stakeholders described goals like â€œmodernizing operationsâ€ and â€œimproving reporting.â€ These are nice words, but they donâ€™t help a project team make decisions.

When I pushed for concrete definitions, we discovered:

  • Some departments wanted S/4HANA mainly for analytics
  • Others wanted automation
  • Some just wanted to fix ongoing ECC issues

Until you understand why the business truly wants S/4HANA â€” beyond the fancy terminology â€” the project will struggle with alignment later.

2. Confirm Whether the â€œRightâ€ Stakeholders Are Even in the Room

This is something Iâ€™ve seen repeatedly, especially in the Middle East region.

During the Discover workshops:

  • A department head would join for the first meeting
  • Then send a junior team member from the second meeting
  • Who was not authorized to make decisions

In one case, we realized the actual process owner from Production Planning wasnâ€™t even involved. This led to misunderstandings and rework.

A realistic business case depends on real decision-makers being identified early.

3. Validate Whether Expected Scope Matches Real Needs

One of my personal beliefs in S/4HANA projects is that scope definition makes or breaks the program.

In our project, the initial scope mentioned only core modules. But after high-level discussions, it became clear that:

  • Treasury Management (TRM)
  • Multi-Bank Connectivity (MBC)
  • IBP (for demand planning)

None of these were reflected in the original budget or timelines.

Discover Phase is the right time to:

  • Validate processes
  • Identify missing modules
  • Check whether additional components are actually necessary

This prevents surprises later.

4. Recheck Cost Assumptions â€” Especially Cloud & Licensing

A very real situation we faced:
The cloud subscription cost was significantly underestimated in the business case.

Once we confirmed:

  • Required number of Fiori users
  • Additional modules
  • Integration add-ons

â€¦the budget increased noticeably.

Licensing and cloud costs must be validated with:

  • SAP
  • The cloud provider
  • Integration and automation tools

If not corrected in Discover, these gaps snowball later.

5. Validate Organizational Readiness (Especially SME Availability)

I strongly believe that SME availability is one of the biggest success factors.

In our project:

  • Some SMEs were handling daily operations
  • Some had never worked on SAP before
  • A few didnâ€™t understand what S/4HANA changes would mean

This directly impacts timelines, testing effort, and even the design.

If SME bandwidth is limited, the business caseâ€™s timeline assumptions must change.

6. Assess Integration and Data Reality Against Assumptions

In our case, the business case assumed:

  • â€œMinimal integrationsâ€
  • â€œData is mostly cleanâ€

Both turned out to be incorrect.

Reality:

  • Several factory systems required real-time integration
  • Historical data archiving was never done
  • Some modules had inconsistent master data ownership

You cannot rely on assumptions made during a sales cycle.
Discover Phase is the moment to validate the actual landscape.

Final Thoughts

The Discover Phase is where the business case either strengthens or collapses.
From my experience managing SAP programs in the Middle East region, the biggest issues in Discover are usually:

  • unclear goals,
  • missing stakeholders,
  • underestimated licensing,
  • additional modules required, and
  • conflicts between departments.

A PMâ€™s job in Discover is not just to review the business case â€” itâ€™s to challenge it, validate it, and correct it based on real conversations and real system realities.

A well-validated business case saves months of pain later.

entry.title: A Practical Real-Time CTI Widget for SAP Sales Cloud V2
entry.content:
Over the last weeks, I've been working on a CTI widget for SAP Sales Cloud V2 and wanted to share the practical setup I used to get it running in a production-ready way. The goal was simple: receive real-time call events from a telephony system and push them into Sales Cloud without relying on any custom back-end inside the CRM.

A small CAP backend, a WebSocket channel, and a UI5 widget were enough to make this work end-to-end.

Overall Architecture

The widget runs in an iframe inside SAP Sales Cloud. A CAP service on BTP receives call events from the telephony provider and forwards them to the widget via WebSocket. The widget then sends a formatted XML payload back to Sales Cloud using postMessage.

 

CAP Service with WebSocket Support

The backend uses CAP v9 with Websocket enabled so the widget can react immediately to incoming call events.

@protocol: ['websocket', 'odata']
service WidgetService {
  action notifyEvent(
      date : String,
      caller : String,
      isAnonymous : String,
      callee : String,
      event : String,
      direction : String,
      LID : String
  ) returns String;

  event eventNotification : CTIEvent;
}

Event Handler is handling the incoming event and emits it to connected WebSocket clients. 

this.on("notifyEvent", async (req) => {
  const eventData = req.data;
  await this.emit('eventNotification', eventData);
  return 'OK';
});

WebSocket channel is enabled using the @cap-js-community/websocket plugin. Also we configured the xs-app.json file.

{
"websockets": {
    "enabled": true
  }
}

Mapping the CTI Event for Sales Cloud

Sales Cloud expects a specific XML payload.
The widget maps incoming CTI data into that format.

function mapToSapPayload(cti) {
  const ev = (cti.event ?? "").toUpperCase();
  const dir = (cti.direction ?? "").toUpperCase();

  let eventType = dir === "OUTBOUND" ? "OUTBOUND" : "INBOUND";
  let action = "NOTIFY";

  switch (ev) {
    case "CONNECTED":
    case "ANSWERED":
      action = "ACCEPT";
      break;
    case "ENDED":
      action = "END";
      eventType = "UPDATEACTIVITY";
      break;
  }

  return {
    Type: "CALL",
    EventType: eventType,
    Action: action,
    ANI: cti.caller || "",
    ExternalReferenceID: cti.LID
  };
}

Sending the Event to Sales Cloud (postMessage)

The widget sends the XML using a postMessage call. After that, SAP Sales Cloud receives it and Desktop Agent creating a new live Interaction. See more in @lloyd_goveia 's post called 'How Can You Simplify SAP Service Cloud CTI Integration Testing? Try This Dynamic POC Widget!'.

const xml = jsonToXml(sapPayload);
window.parent.postMessage(xml, "*");

Here is an example payload. See more in SAP Help Portal.

<payload>
  <Type>CALL</Type>
  <EventType>INBOUND</EventType>
  <Action>NOTIFY</Action>
  <ANI>+123456789</ANI>
  <ExternalReferenceID>CALL123</ExternalReferenceID>
</payload>

SAP Sales Cloud reads sent mesagge only if CTI is enabled for the tenant, follow the SAP Help Portal doc for more detail. 

Security Notes

The SAP Sales Cloud domain was added to the App Router allowlist (whitelist) to ensure that SAP Cloud is able to load the widget in an iframe. we need to configure the whitelistService propery in xs-app.json.

{
  "whitelistService": {
    "endpoint": "/whitelist/service"
  },
  "responseHeaders": [
    {
      "name": "Content-Security-Policy",
      "value": "frame-ancestors https://*.crm.cloud.sap"
    }
  ],
  "routes": [
    {
      "source": "^/whitelist/service$",
      "localDir": ".",
      "authenticationType": "none",
      "cacheControl": "no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate"
    }
}

For more information, please visit @sap/approuter in npmjs.com.

Configure SAP Sales Cloud CTI Configuration

There are a few CTI settings that need to be enable first to make the widget show up inside SAP Sales Cloud V2. 

  • Enable CTI Integration --> See SAP Help Portal
  • Register the Widget --> See SAP Help Portal 

Source Code 

The base code is available on Github as a public repo.

Repository Name: gizemsoylutr/sales-cloud-cti-widget

entry.title: Demystifying MCP: A Practical Journey to AI-Powered Commerce with SAP
entry.content:
Introduction

In the past years, we have seen how AIâ€™s has evolved, we have seen how LLMâ€™s that can understand natural language, respond back in natural language, do coding in multiple language etc and we saw the evolution from LLMS to RAG, FineTuning, Agentic AI and what not.

Not so recently we also came to know about the new paradigm named MCP or Model Context Protocol and this Blog or this series of Blog is my humble attempt to understand MCP and document my hands-on journey starting from my comfort zone, SAP Commerce cloud.

So I always approach a problem with three questions. What, Why and How. So In this Initial Blog I will try to capture the What, Why and How. And then we will eventually dive into a more practical hands-on.

The What Why and How

I never have the intention to reinvent the wheel and explain to you on What is MCP and what is the gap it is going to fill, or rather the WHY, but will add the link to Reference from official website for review and for a quick note this is my sort of explanation

What

MCP is  "The Model Context Protocol (MCP)" is an open standard that standardises how large language models (LLMs) connect to and communicate with external tools and data sources.

How

  • LLM acting as a MCP Client needs information to complete a task
  • It sends the request to a MCP server which resides in a different system to get tools and data
  • The MCP protocol defines the standard
  • The MCP server will in turn connect to Local Server, API etc to fetch data
  • The MCP Server returns the data to the Client/LLM
  • And this whole process is repeated with different servers to make the things autonomous.

Why MCP

From a developer perceptive, MCP reduces the development time and complexity when building or integrating with and AI application or agent.

From AI Agent perspective, MCP provides access to an ecosystem of data sourcesm tools and apps.

From and end-users perspective MCP results in more capable AI applications or AI Agents which can take real actions on behalf of you.

Confused, lets breakdown.

To understand it better on the What, How and Why, I thought of taking a simple example from a day to day activity - shopping an item from any of the portal of your choice.

I am taking the following example.

ğŸƒ â€œFind me the best camera under â‚¹10,000 and add it to my cart.â€

Now if we look from what would happen in real life is anyone who wants to buy online will search for camera in the app or web portal of their favourite shopping app and they will find n number of items with similar spec and similar price from different brand and you are confused on which is best. This is known as the paradox of decision and we will see how MCP can help in here with all these advancement over the years

Note: There might be â€˜nâ€™ number of other techniques in AI but we are limiting to these options highlighted above

My Learning RoadMap

Iâ€™m diving this into two phases.

Phase 1: We will get into the basics of MCP and setup things in Local

  • Understand MCP Architecture
  • Setting up LLMs, MCP, Commerce and Integration in local
  • Building a practical use case

Phase 2: Migrating to BTP

  • Setup Git Hub Project for MCP configurations and Commerce
  • Deploy MCP in BTP
  • Host Commerce in CCV2
  • Run the sample again

Closing Thoughts

AI alone can make things smarter.
But MCP makes AI smarter by giving the tools and context.

For me, this isnâ€™t just about building another integration â€” itâ€™s about exploring the next frontier of commerce intelligence.

Stay tuned as we start our journey into the world of AI-augmented shopping â€” adding the best camera in my cart

Coming Next:

  • Part 1 â€“ Understanding MCP: The Brain Behind Collaborative AI
  • Part 2 - Building the MCP Server and client for SAP Commerce in Local

entry.title: Working with Custom Code List in SAP Sales/Service Cloud V2
entry.content:
Introduction

SAP Service/Sales Cloud V2 has following  extensibility options:

  1. In-app admin extensions â€“ fields, layouts, mashups
  2. Low Code No Code extensions with SAP Build
  3. Complex extensions with BTP

In this blog we will focus on In-app admin extensions and in particular, creation and usage of Custom Code List.

 

Create Custom Code List

Sample Use-Case:  

Your Business needs  to capture the type of real-estate in the newly created Leads , they want this field to be a dropdown list with single value selection option . As an administrator you need to create this extension and add that to Lead object.

Prerequisite: 

Please ensure that you have Admin rights and your business role has customCodeListService and the Custom Code Lists  admin app added.

  

 

 

 

Step-by-Step process to create Custom Code List :

1.  Log in into your SAP Sales /Service Cloud V2 tenant as an admin and go to Setting -> Extensibility ->Custom Code List and create a Custom Code List by filling the details such as Code List ID, Name, Default Language.

 

 

 

 

 

2. Once you have populated other details, you have option of choosing sorting options. You can choose Ascending/Descending and sorting by Code or Description. In our example we choose Ascending and Code as sorting options.

 

 

 

 

 

3. Once you have saved the newly created Custom Code  List, you are now in the details screen, where you have to add the values(Code & Description) as shown below.

 4. Now your Custom Code List is ready to be added to different entities, you can add the Custom Code List to multiple entities. In our example we add this to Lead. Go to Settings -> All Settings  -> Extensibility and click on Extensibility Administration and search for â€˜Lead'  business entity, select the Lead and go to tab â€˜Custom Fieldsâ€™ and click on â€˜+â€™ .

 

5. Populate the required details of the new custom field such as Label, Technical Name, select the Data Type as String and Data Format as Code. Now select the checkbox for Custom which will give you the option of choosing the Custom Code List created earlier.(if you need a multi value selector, select the Multi Value checkbox as well).

 

Once you save your changes, you will notice that two fields are created, one for Code and one for Description.

6. We are done with Custom Code List creation and have extended the Lead entity. Next step is to add the newly created Custom Code list to the UI. Select the Start Adaptation from user menu.

7. We are in adaptation mode as shown below, now select the section of the screen where you want to add the code list and click on edit.

8. Click on Add from List button and select Extensions as shown below.

9. You will see the Custom Code List which we created earlier, select that and click on Apply.

10. Exit from the Adaptation mode and you will find the field added on the UI.

 

Conclusion

Congratulations you have created and used the Custom Code List. Some of the things which you should keep in mind       are :

  1. Currently you can create a maximum of 100 Custom Code Lists.
  2. Each Code List can contain upto 2000 values.

entry.title: Understanding the "Account Document Output" App and Customizing Form Templates
entry.content:
The "Account Document Output" app is a powerful tool designed to streamline the display and printing of debit and credit postings for various general ledger accounts, in compliance with Chinese legal requirements. Here's a closer look at its functionality and how users can customize the forms to suit their specific needs.

ä¸€. What Does the "Account Document Output" App Do?
The main purpose of this app is to provide users with flexibility in displaying and printing accounting documents. It offers three output types: ALV list, PDF preview, and PDF direct printing. This versatility allows users to view accounting documents according to their preferences and needs. Key features of the app include:
a)Output Types: Users can choose between ALV list, PDF preview, and PDF direct printing for viewing accounting vouchers.
b)View Switching: Support for toggling between general ledger view and entry view.
c)Document Type Selection: Provides options for selecting different accounting document types.
d)Batch Printing: On the Cloud, users can set up printer queues and specify default print forms for direct batch printing of accounting documents.
äºŒ.Customization options while printing:
PDF Report Title, Accountant Manager, Approver: Users can specify headers and signature lines to appear during voucher printing.
Alternative Account Number: Supports the display of alternative account numbers when printing vouchers.
Batch Input Sorting Field: Users can set the sorting criteria when displaying accounting documents in batches, such as sorting by official voucher number by month.

ä¸‰.Customizing Form Templates

Open the app "Maintain Form Templates," and enter "IDCN_ACC_DOC_OM" in the form template name filter. Click the "Download" icon on the details page of the "IDCN_ACC_DOC_OM" form template to download the SAP preset form template. Unzip the downloaded package, open Adobe Live Cycle Designer, and open the file IDCN_ACC_DOC_OM_E.xdp extracted from the package.

  1. If you want to adjust the layout of the preset form by adding a column to display the cost center of the document:

    a. Open the form IDCN_ACC_DOC_OM_E.xdp using Adobe Live Cycle Designer, and add a new field in the form layout.

    b. Switch to the Data View tab in Adobe Live Cycle Designer, and drag the Ktosl field into the highlighted area for the cost center column, as shown in the screenshot below.

  2. For fixed asset documents, if you want the "Details" column to show the account/asset master data description instead of just the fixed asset number during printing:

    a. Open the form IDCN_ACC_DOC_OM_E.xdp using Adobe LiveCycle Designer. Double-click the cell where you want to add or modify the script to open the script editor.
    In this example, double-click the highlighted "Details" column in yellow; the upper half of the window will show the script editor.

    b. Modify the existing script code by adding the code highlighted in yellow. The goal is to display the account description in addition to the account number and asset number when the account type of the line item is a fixed asset.
    (In this example, only the form that displays in the company currency and is a non-alternative account is modified.)



    Reopen the "Maintain Form Templates" app, switch to the "Custom Templates" tab, and click the "Create" icon. In the pop-up window, enter the following information:
  • Form Template Name: Maintain the form template name according to your company's naming conventions.
  • Language: If the downloaded preset form template is in English, select "English" here; otherwise, choose accordingly.
  • Select Form Template File: Choose the xdp file updated in Adobe Live Cycle Designer.
  • Data Source: Choose the Chinese accounting document print data source "FDP_IDCN_ACC_DOC_SRV."

On the next screen, in the "Available Countries" field, select "China." If there is a translated Chinese version of the template later, you can click "New Translation" to upload the customized Chinese xdp document. Then click "Save" to save your customized template.

Hope the information could help you.

Best regards,

Lola

entry.title: Printing Account Document Output
entry.content:
ä¸€. Activate Document Numbering for Company Code
When the "Activate" field is checked, it indicates that the official document numbering feature is enabled for that company code. It is generally recommended to check this option.
If the "Post-Generate" field is selected, it means that the official document number will be generated at the time of document printing. This is the recommended option.
Note: If "Post-Generate" is not selected, the official document number will be generated in real-time during the accounting document posting. Due to technical limitations, this approach is currently not recommended.

äºŒ. Batch Printing
a)Choose the "Maintain Print Queues" app under the Output Management group.
b)Click New to maintain a new print queue.

c)Use the existing print user or create a new one.
d)Open the Accounts Document Output - China app.
e)Fill in the Printer, Print Form and choose "PDF Direct Printing" under "Output Type".
f)Cloud Printer Manager
a. Set Security Protocol to 'Transport Layer Security (TLS) 1.2'.

b. Create new Runtime System and Test Connection.

 

c. Assign a printer.

d. Click OK to print and wait for several minutes, and all the documents will be printed.

Hope the information could help you!

Best regards,

Lola

entry.title: Re: Preventing Negative Balances in Cost Centers in SAP P...
entry.content:
Thanks Alvaro for your question and thanks Chris for the excellent answer.

There is a reason for not providing checks to prevent negative balances on cost centers.
Depending on the cost allocation method you use, negative balances can occur and are not by default something you want to prevent.

  • If universal allocation is used to move costs from cost centers to other receivers, you normally define a rule that moves 100% of the costs to other receivers, this method ensures a balance of zero on the sending cost center at period end.
  • With activity allocation cost centers normally have a balance at period end, if. e.g. cost postings are still missing or the cost rates are too high, this balance could also run below zero.
    In this case a balance check could for example prevent time confirmations and this is very often something you do not want to have.
    Therefore it is sometimes better to not directly block postings but ensure that someone gets informed if the balance runs below zero. Because as said, this does not always mean that something is wrong.

Again thanks for connecting and discussing via the SAP Community.

Best regards, Birgit

entry.title: Extensibility of Account Document Output
entry.content:
ä¸€. Extensibility of Account Document Output:
Extensibility of Account Document Output Enhancements can be made using the "Custom Logic" app:
1)If users want to sort by line item number for documents with many line items in the document printing form, this can be achieved using the business add-in under the business context "China: Account Document Output" with the enhancement "China: Customizing Set Account Document." You can refer to the example logic by clicking "Example" in the upper right corner.

 

2)To add additional fields (including custom fields) of accounting document line items to the document printing form, use the business add-in "China: Customizing Set Account Document" in the business context "China: Account Document Output." Refer to example logic by clicking "Example" in the upper right corner.

3)If users want the "Primary Account" field in the document printing form to display information about the Level=1 node corresponding to the line item's general ledger account, use the business add-in "China: Display Level 1 Account in Account Document" under the business context "China: Account Document Output Account Hierarchy." Refer to example logic by clicking "Example" in the upper right corner.

4)For specific business scenarios, if users want to merge similar line items in the document printing form, such as merging line items with the same accounting account/material number from logistics module postings, this can be achieved using the business add-in "China: Merge Line Items for Printing" under the business context "China: Merge Line Items for Printing." Refer to example logic by clicking "Example" in the upper right corner.

 

Hope the information could help you!

Best regards,

Lola

entry.title: Standardize Resource Creation with Reusable Resource Types in SAP Fieldglass
entry.content:
Tired of re-entering the same details for every contractor or piece of equipment? Resource types help you prefill and control data so you can create resources faster and with fewer errors.

If youâ€™re spending time manually keying addresses, job codes, or work schedules for every new resourceâ€”and still ending up with inconsistent recordsâ€”youâ€™re not alone. That repetition slows onboarding, complicates audits, and makes creating resource records harder than it needs to be.

What You Can Do with SAP Fieldglass

  • Build once, reuse everywhere: With resource types, you define the basicsâ€”labor or equipment, address, job code, time tracking, work schedule, activity checklist, and moreâ€”once. Then you use that resource type as a template any time you create a resource.
  • Reduce data entry and improve quality: Admins can lock, hide, or default specific fields in the resource type. That means fewer fields to touch, fewer errors to chase, and standardized data across business units and suppliers. When you create a resource from a type, key fields and any custom fields carry over automatically.
  • Engage both labor and equipment: Resource types support people and assets. Labor resources can register and log in to SAP Fieldglass to manage and complete assigned work items (for example, SOW line items).
  • Keep governance and visibility: The system audit trail records create, edit, and remove activities for resource types. Reporting is straightforward, with data points such as Resource ID, Equipment ID, Equipment Name, and Type available. If you use integrations, the Resource Upload and Resource Download connectors support this capability for bulk operations.

How it works (at a glance):

  1. Create a resource type from Admin > Worker > Resource Type, and set defaults (labor or equipment, job code, time tracking, work schedule, and any required checklists or custom fields).
  2. Create a resource by selecting that type; the predefined fields are applied automatically.
  3. Activate the resource. Labor resources receive an email invitation to register and then move to Open; equipment resources move directly to Open on activation.

 Caveats & Tips

  • Permissions first. Make sure the right user role permissions are enabled for the Resource Type module before you start.
  • Pick the right type up front. Resource records inherit whether the type is Labor or Equipment; that choice determines the lifecycle and what the resource can do.
  • Plan activation. If you donâ€™t enable auto activation, new resources start in Pending Activation. Labor resources receive an invitation email to create an SAP Fieldglass account upon activation, and then move to Open. Equipment resources move directly to Open on activation.
  • Govern with custom fields. Use custom fieldsâ€”and the ability to lock, hide, or default valuesâ€”to enforce naming conventions, cost centers, locations, or other critical attributes. You can create custom fields specific to labor or equipment.

What to Do Next

  • Set up reusable templates for labor or equipment: Creating a Resource Type (SAP Help Portal).
  • Quickly create resources from your templates: Creating a Resource (SAP Help Portal).

entry.title: Fetching ErrorInformation from CPI Message Processing Logs
entry.content:
The Challenge

The CPI environment uses External Logging to send logs to Splunk. There, the LastError field is readily available:

Important: The LastError field is also populated for messages with status COMPLETED - when an error was caught and handled properly in the iFlow. This is valuable for monitoring because you can see errors that were gracefully handled and potentially returned to the sender system, even though the message processing itself succeeded.

However, when querying the OData v2 API (/api/v1/MessageProcessingLogs), this field is not exposed. The ErrorInformation is only available as a deferred navigation property:

{
  "ErrorInformation": {
    "__deferred": {
      "uri": ".../MessageProcessingLogErrorInformations('guid')"
    }
  }
}

What I Tested

$expand=ErrorInformation

GET /MessageProcessingLogs?$expand=ErrorInformation

Result: 501 Not Implemented

This is the most obvious approach, but CPI doesn't support it. There are SAP Influence requests for this:

  • #296909
  • #309960

$select=LastError

GET /MessageProcessingLogs('guid')?$select=MessageGuid,LastError,Status

Result: Field not available in API response

The LastError field exists internally (Splunk receives it), but is not exposed via OData.

OData $batch Request

POST /$batch
Content-Type: multipart/mixed; boundary=batch_123

Result: 404 - The $batch endpoint doesn't exist for MessageProcessingLogErrorInformations

What Works

The only method I found is calling each message individually:

GET /MessageProcessingLogErrorInformations('MessageGuid')/$value

This returns the plain text error message. But for thousands of messages, this means thousands of API calls.

Open Question

I'm currently using parallel HTTP requests as a workaround, but it feels inefficient when Splunk already receives this data automatically via External Logging.

Has anyone found a better approach? Maybe there's an undocumented feature or a way to access the External Logging stream directly?

Let me know in the comments!

Updating the printer driver and explicitly setting paper size and source in PrintOptions usually resolves it.

entry.title: Re: where we can see system landscape in my s4hana cloud...
entry.content:
Dear @bcrao,

In a Public Cloud 3-system landscape, CBC is connected only to the development line (Starter + DEV). So in CBC you wonâ€™t see the Test and Production systems as connected systems the same way you see DEV

More details below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3610729

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a630d57fc5004c6383e7a81efee7a8bb/aa60b129af7b4ce8ae052618c8315d29.html

In CBC -> Settings and switch workspace, you will see the systems/tenants for DEV

 

 

 


In a 3-system landscape, CBC shows these deployment targets:

  • Starter system: Starter Customizing tenant + Starter Development tenant
  • Development system (DEV): Customizing tenant + Development tenant

You typically find/access TEST and PROD via:

  1. SAP for Me this is where systems are requested/provisioned and where tenant access info is referenced in SAP documentation

 

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/53e36b5493804bcdb3f6f14de8b487dd/3efdad479e5f47dba4d7cb65966c1a5c.html

If you canâ€™t see TEST/PROD in SAP for Me, itâ€™s usually an authorization issue, so your administrator needs to grant access to system data

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: From MCQs to Real Skills: My Experience with SAPâ€™s New Certification Format
entry.content:
What Exactly has changed ?

SAP is gradually moving selected certifications away from multiple-choice questions to a scenario-based, practical, hands-on evaluation model.

Instead of selecting the right choice in a MCQ pattern, you now :

  • Configure or Build something
  • Work on real scenarios
  • Receive a defined input and produce an output that is automatically validated against the expected outcome
  • Submit the output 
  • Get evaluated automatically through AI-driven checks

 

Why I personally liked the format 

âœ”ï¸It rewards real experience 

âœ”ï¸No more memorizing dumps 

âœ”ï¸Open-book = Realistic 

âœ”ï¸Dumps are meaningless now 

 

Who will benefit from this change ?

  • Experienced professionals 
  • New learners 
  • Employers 
  • SAP ecosystem 

 

Which certifications supports this New Format ?

SAP has rolled out the practical, scenario-based exam to six certifications:

Certification Portfolio with Practical Exam 

 

Tips If You're Preparing for This New Exam

  • Practice hands-on tasks 
  • Build small end-to-end examples 
  • Use SAP Help effectively 
  • Focus on solving problems, not memorizing 
 

Conclusion

This new certification format is a huge step forward. It is fair, practical, and aligned with modern SAP project work. Focus on practice, not memory.
